pytket.transform¶

class pytket._tket.transform.CXConfigType¶

Enum for available configurations for CXs upon decompose phase gadgets

Members:

Snake : linear nearest neighbour CX sequence. Linear depth.

Star : Every CX has same target, linear depth, good for gate cancellation.

Tree : Balanced tree: logarithmic depth, harder to route.

__init__(self: pytket._tket.transform.CXConfigType, arg0: int) → None¶
property name¶

(self: handle) -> str

class pytket._tket.transform.PauliSynthStrat¶

Enum for available strategies to synthesise Pauli gadgets

Members:

Individual : Synthesise gadgets individually

Pairwise : Synthesise gadgets using an efficient pairwise strategy from Cowtan et al (https://arxiv.org/abs/1906.01734)

Sets : Synthesise gadgets in commuting sets

__init__(self: pytket._tket.transform.PauliSynthStrat, arg0: int) → None¶
property name¶

(self: handle) -> str

class pytket._tket.transform.Transform¶

An in-place transformation of a Circuit.

CommuteSQThroughSWAP(device: tket::Device) → pytket._tket.transform.Transform¶

Commutes single qubit gates through SWAP gates, leaving them on the physical qubit wtih best fidelity for given gate type. Assumes the circuit is already mapped onto the architecture.

Parameters

device – The device to use for connectivity and fidelity information

CommuteThroughMultis() → pytket._tket.transform.Transform¶

Applies a collection of commutation rules to move single qubit operations past multiqubit operations they commute with, towards the front of the circuit.

DecomposeBRIDGE() → pytket._tket.transform.Transform¶

Decomposes all BRIDGE gates into CX gates.

DecomposeBoxes() → pytket._tket.transform.Transform¶

Decomposes all Boxed operations into elementary gates.

DecomposeCCX() → pytket._tket.transform.Transform¶

Decomposes all 3-qubit Toffoli (CCX) gates into Clifford+T gates.

DecomposeCXDirected(arc: pytket._tket.routing.Architecture) → pytket._tket.transform.Transform¶

Decompose CX gates to H+CX to match the direction of the CXs to edges of the Architecture arc. Assumes the circuit already satisfies the connectivity of arc.

Parameters

arc – The architecture for which CXs should be redirected

DecomposeControlledRys() → pytket._tket.transform.Transform¶

Decomposes all arbitrarily-quantum-controlled Rys into CX and Ry gates.

DecomposeSWAP(circuit: pytket._tket.circuit.Circuit) → pytket._tket.transform.Transform¶

Decomposes all SWAP gates to provided replacement circuit.

Parameters

circuit – A circuit that is logically equivalent to a SWAP operation

DecomposeSWAPtoCX(arc: pytket._tket.routing.Architecture = <tket::Architecture, nodes=0>) → pytket._tket.transform.Transform¶

Decomposes all SWAP gates into triples of CX gates. If the SWAP is adjacent to a CX, it will prefer to insert in the direction that allows for gate cancellation. If an Architecture is provided, this will prefer to insert the CXs such that fewer need redirecting.

Parameters

arc – Device architecture used to specify a preference for CX direction

KAKDecomposition() → pytket._tket.transform.Transform¶

Identifies two-qubit subcircuits with more than 3 CXs and reduces them via the KAK/Cartan decomposition, using the method detailed in https://arxiv.org/abs/cond-mat/0609750. The replacement subcircuits use CX, U3, S, Sdg, Rz, Ry gates.

OptimiseCliffords(allow_swaps: bool = True) → pytket._tket.transform.Transform¶

An optimisation pass that performs a number of rewrite rules for simplifying Clifford gate sequences, similar to Duncan & Fagan (https://arxiv.org/abs/1901.10114). Given a circuit with CXs and any single-qubit gates, produces a circuit with Z, X, S, V, U1, U2, U3, CX gates. This will not preserve CX placement or orientation and may introduce implicit wire swaps.

Parameters

allow_swaps – dictates whether the rewriting will disregard CX placement or orientation and introduce wire swaps.

OptimisePauliGadgets(cx_config: pytket._tket.transform.CXConfigType = CXConfigType.Snake) → pytket._tket.transform.Transform¶

An optimisation pass that identifies the Pauli gadgets corresponding to any non-Clifford rotations and synthesises them pairwise (see Cowtan, Duncan, Dilkes, Simmons, & Sivarajah https://arxiv.org/abs/1906.01734). Results use Z, X, S, V, U1, U2, U3, CX gates.

OptimisePhaseGadgets(cx_config: pytket._tket.transform.CXConfigType = CXConfigType.Snake) → pytket._tket.transform.Transform¶

An optimisation pass that starts by identifying subcircuits corresponding to phase gadgets (see Cowtan, Duncan, Dilkes, Simmons, & Sivarajah https://arxiv.org/abs/1906.01734) and resynthesises them in a balanced-tree form, followed by applying OptimisePostRouting. Results use U1, U2, U3, CX gates. This will not preserve CX placement or orientation.

OptimisePostRouting() → pytket._tket.transform.Transform¶

Fast optimisation pass, performing basic simplifications. Works on any circuit, giving the result in U1, U2, U3, CX gates. If all multi-qubit gates are CXs, then this preserves their placement and orientation, so it is safe to perform after routing.

RebaseToCirq() → pytket._tket.transform.Transform¶

Rebase from any gate set into PhasedX, Rz, CZ.

RebaseToCliffordSingles() → pytket._tket.transform.Transform¶

Identify Clifford-angle rotations (from U1, U2, U3, Rx, Ry, Rz), replacing them with Z, X, S, V gates. Any non-Clifford rotations will stay as they are.

RebaseToProjectQ() → pytket._tket.transform.Transform¶

Rebase from any gate set into the gate set supported by ProjectQ (Rx, Ry, Rz, X, Y, Z, S, T, V, H, CX, CZ, CRz, SWAP).

RebaseToPyZX() → pytket._tket.transform.Transform¶

Rebase from any gate set into the gate set supported by PyZX (Rx, Rz, X, Z, S, T, H, CX, CZ, SWAP).

RebaseToQiskit() → pytket._tket.transform.Transform¶

Rebase from any gate set into U1, U2, U3, CX.

RebaseToQuil() → pytket._tket.transform.Transform¶

Rebase from any gate set into Rx, Rz, CZ.

RebaseToRzRx() → pytket._tket.transform.Transform¶

Rebase single qubit gates into Rz, Rx.

ReduceSingles() → pytket._tket.transform.Transform¶

Reduces any sequence of single qubit rotations into a single U1/U3 gate.

RemoveRedundancies() → pytket._tket.transform.Transform¶

Applies a collection of simple optimisations, such as removing gate-inverse pairs, merging similar rotation gates, and removing identity gates. Preserves the gate set and any placement/orientation of multi-qubit gates.

SynthesisePauliGraph(synth_strat: pytket._tket.transform.PauliSynthStrat = PauliSynthStrat.Sets, cx_config: pytket._tket.transform.CXConfigType = CXConfigType.Snake) → pytket._tket.transform.Transform¶

Synthesises Pauli Graphs.

UCCSynthesis(synth_strat: pytket._tket.transform.PauliSynthStrat = PauliSynthStrat.Sets, cx_config: pytket._tket.transform.CXConfigType = CXConfigType.Snake) → pytket._tket.transform.Transform¶

Synthesises UCC circuits in the form that Term Sequencing provides them.

__init__()¶

Initialize self. See help(type(self)) for accurate signature.

apply(self: pytket._tket.transform.Transform, circuit: pytket._tket.circuit.Circuit) → bool¶

Performs the transformation on the circuit in place.

Parameters

circuit – The circuit to be transformed

Returns

Whether any changes were successfully made

repeat(transform: pytket._tket.transform.Transform) → pytket._tket.transform.Transform¶

Applies a given Transform repeatedly to a circuit until no further changes are made (i.e. it no longer returns True). apply() will return True if at least one run returned True.

Parameters

transform – The Transform to be applied repeatedly

Returns

A new Transform representing the iteration

sequence(sequence: List[pytket._tket.transform.Transform]) → pytket._tket.transform.Transform¶

Composes a list of Transforms together in sequence. The apply() method will return True if ANY of the individual Transforms returned True.

Parameters

sequence – The list of Transforms to be composed

Returns

The combined Transform

while_repeat(condition: pytket._tket.transform.Transform, body: pytket._tket.transform.Transform) → pytket._tket.transform.Transform¶

Repeatedly applies the condition Transform until it returns False, running body in between each condition application. Intuitively, this corresponds to “WHILE condition DO body”.

Parameters

  • condition – The Transform to be applied repeatedly as the condition of a loop

  • body – The Transform to be applied after each successful test of the condition

Returns

A new Transform representing the iteration
